title: Cycling Plus May issue on sale now! Subscribe and receive a free Lezyne Smart Grip Mount worth £25
content:
In this latest issue the Cycling Plus team dissects the numbers of Strava’s Year in Sport report by speaking to those riders who defied the odds. How can you prepare for the world’s biggest mountains by riding on the flat? The team shows you how, and Cycling Plus’s intrepid reporter James Witts investigates why bikes are now more expensive and harder to find.

Also in this issue, chief technical editor Warren Rossiter gets first rides of the The Light Blue Newnham and Shand Leveret, while features editor John Whitney gives the Salsa Warbird Carbon GRX 600 gravel bike a spin.

  • Subscribe to Cycling Plus to receive your free gift as well as discounts and more

Mountain high

Lockdown restrictions have made travel difficult, so for those cyclists craving for the Alps or Pyrenees, the team has spoken to those in the know about how to gain high-mountain skills on the molehills of Britain.

Superbike me

Superbikes can feel as though they have the worth of a small nation’s GDP, so the Cycling Plus team tested out four affordable versions that ring in at less than £3000, proving that it is possible to get aero for less.

Smart thinking

While bike computers take care of your data when riding, a smart watch can tell you your heart rate, sleep patterns, diet and recovery status. It’s a busy market, so to make it easy the team found six of the best for cyclists.

Scot’s away!

On a sunny, wintry afternoon, Cycling Plus headed out to the hills of Perthshire to soak in the grandeur and beauty of the area and to meet audax hero and local legend George ‘McNasty’ Berwick. An 80-year-old with plenty to say…
